ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q4: Susan assigns A LOT of reading, and I never was able to keep up with it. But it was nice because it really seemed as though she understood that we would not realistically be able to do all of the reading she assigned.Q7: Not everyone is going to enjoy a class with Susan Clark. Some people love her, and some just don't like her style.

I think it would be a good idea to move the presentations to earlier in the semester. This would build a trusting atmosphere in the room that could benefit later discussions.Some case studies of groups or organizations applying principles from the readings would be nice.
Wonderful class, topic, and professor! Need more of these classes that are interdisciplinary and examine environmental psychology!

#2: The professor provided a nice overview of the material, but it was almost simplistic. I would like a more substantial presentation of the readings.#10: This course is unique. Although it's not related to the technical program for the master of forestry degree, it is an interesting class and pertains to understanding the person. Understanding this the person will help me in my professional career when I work with the public. The class also provides a platform to express ourselves in a way that we cannot in other courses at FES. This is invaluable.
The presentations about ourselves
It gets you thinking critically about yourself, analyzing your fears and influences.
Discussions and powerpoints at end.
The topic: environmental psychology
Class time, discussion of readings, Angela's activities that she led in class, student presentations

Everything! I loved the concepts, readings, class discussions, and individual/student presentations. This class was the reason I came back to graduate school - it revolutionized how I think about the world and myself. I LOVED this class.
Our presentations, because it was a deep exploration into myself and I learned about my peers in a special way, that would not have occurred outside of this class.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: it was hard to understand exactly what some of the takehome messages were from some of the lectures. listening to people talk at the end of the year, it was clear that some material resonated with everyone and some material did not stick with anyone. i think more explicitly talking through some of these other issues, if they are important to understand, would be worthwhile.
The amount of reading required from the class was too much. Most of the students in the class seemed not to have time to read most of the papers.
More weekly journal assignments/direction; however, the flexibility was important too...
It would be nice to delve more deeply into the course topics.

Some of the class readings posted online got cut off when they were being scanned and were un-readable when we printed them off. A few guest speakers may have been fun (but it certainly was fine this semester without them).
I would like the lectures to be more solid and more developed.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both Angela and Susan are great. They are always willing to talk about whatever is on your mind about the class or life in general.
Great
Excellent!

Both Angela and Professor Clark were extremely helpful, Professor Clark encouraged students to come to office hours which I appreciated, and Angela was available around Kroon and over email to answer questons, she was very helpful in discussing the readings and always had time. I also enjoyed the class she taught, and the activities she led in class.
Both the instructor and the TA were always available and responsive to student questions.
The TA was always available, as was the instructor. The instructor once did not respond to my e-mail.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am interested in environmental education, and this class fit very nicely because it taught us about how to talk to other people about values and big, important issues. mostly, it made us learn about ourselves, which i think is important for anyone who is going to put themselves out there for people.
Understanding ourselves and others is fundamental to solving environmental problem solving.
Amazing, fits into ANY program!
It is a topic I want to explore more, possibly through a Ph.D. program.
To understand how to engage with people who are in opposition to the environmental agenda

I am looking to pursue a career in environmental/conservation psychology, so this class is the most relevant class I have taken at FES. Understanding our own behavior/limitations/weaknesses helps us improve ourselves as individuals and as professionals. It then helps us to understand the behavior/thought process of others, and is crucial to any line of work/job we end up doing. This class is extremely relevant to all of FES students, staff, and faculty. It is imperative that FES offer more social science classes like this to its students. This should without a doubt be a foundations course for FES students.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: i wanted to learn more abouthow the human mind works in relation to environmental understanding.
To learn and explore.
The topic, and the fact it was taught by Susan Clark.

Understanding he relationship between society and natural resources is one of the most important skills for environmental professionals, I wish there were more courses that focused on this topic. From this course I learned most about understanding the viewpoints of those that are very different from FES types, like with the Youtube video by a group in Montana that opposed wolf reintroduction. I feel better prepared to engage with people from vastly different viewpoints and backgrounds after this course.
I am looking to pursue a career in environmental/conservation psychology, and am extremely interested in understanding/studying human-nature interactions.
It's an interesting topic that I wanted to explore. It's a nice complement to the technical courses offered at FES.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: i learned less about that and more about how my own mind works, which was just as good.
Maybe
Yes
Yes
Exceeded
It exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: see above.
Yes
Yes

Yes--I am coming away with an understanding of the stages of adult cognitive development, existentialism and existential fears, Laswell's values and how they drive decision making, and a better understanding of myself and how to develop as a leader and communicator
Yes, and more.

I don't feel I am well-versed in theories of environmental sociology and psychology. The course was a bit too cursory for me. I didn't expect to bond with my colleagues as I did. This course presents a model for human relationships.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: go to the first couple classes and see if you gel with susan. if you like her, you will love this class. if you don't see yourself getting along well with susan, you are going to hate every minute of the class.
This is very different from most classes at FES. In many ways the class is about understanding yourself.There is a lot of reading required.
Take this class and tell FES' administration and Dean that you want more truly interdisciplinary classes like this one!

Do the readings (all of them) to get the most out of discussions, don't stress too much about your 30 minute presentation (but practice it, be prepared to share your own perspectives and background with the class, prepare to grow professionally, personally

TAKE THIS CLASS! The class revolutionized how I think about the world and myself. Hands down, this seminar been the most helpful, exciting and thought-provoking class I have taken as both a graduate and undergraduate student. I highly, highly recommend this course.
